SENT.plain: While venous manifestations are common in Behçet disease and often occur as a presenting feature, thromboses of the vena cava are less frequent and usually occur several years after onset
We report the unusual case of a patient whose Behçet disease was revealed by vena cava thrombosis
Most authors underscore the difficulties encountered in ascribing vena cava thrombosis to Behçet disease and the frequent latency of inferior vena cava involvement

Pathological changes in these venous thromboses are identical to those found in other organs involved in Behçet disease: they consist in inflammation of the venous wall with perivascularitis and secondary thrombosis
Lastly, there is a general agreement as to the adverse prognostic significance of the venous involvement
